reviewText:
This game is quite flawed, walk into it knowing that.

The first thing I did (as I do with most games) is open whatever configuration options the game makes available, and unfortunately for us, the graphics options leave much to be desired. The configuration screen seems more to set your resolution and generic quality dropboxes than tweak the game to work on your system. Thankfully, most PCs should be able to run this fine (I run it at a native 1366x768 at High on a laptop released two or so years ago) and it looks quite nice.

This is also a game you must play with attention paid to the story. The game has excellent writing and a sense of humour that gets me every time. Heck, the tutorial teaches you how to play by telling you to ruin this world's version of Christmas, and then the main game encourages you to go seal clubbing. The great writing often carries the game through rougher bits, like the odd graphical glitches that can cause a minion's eyes to momentarily dislodge from its body or the wonky minion AI that compels my Reds to walk up and punch the vicious hunter. But playing as many glitchy, underpolished games as I have rather immunizes me to these kinds of things so I can look past them and still find the plethora of fun.

Many improvements have been made over the first. For instance, the player is now a dangerous force in combat, spells are much more useful, and minions are less inclined to drown themselves. Minor nigglings like the amount of effort needed to craft weapons have been addressed, and minions have much more personality now. In fact, you can even choose to have certain favourites come back from death, and you ca track the title and level of each throughout the course of the game. It makes equipping certain minions less of gamble because you don't lose the fancy gladius when Beezer the Seal Slayer gets mauled out in the field.

Overall, Overlord II is a game you need to adjust your expectations for. It's not the most complicated game (puzzles are often just assigning certain minions to a task) and the combat often devolves to chucking brown minions at anything that so much as breathes but it's the heart the game wears on its sleeve that makes it a worthwhile purchase. And at an impulse-friendly $10, it's not really that big of a ounch to the pocketbook if you walk away feeling unfulfilled with the game's antics.

reviewText:
More of the same from Overlord 1, with some improvements, not enough improvements. The good stuff is still here, and the bad stuff is mostly still here.

The good stuff:

- Funny and fun game! The cheerful villainy of Overlord 1 is still here, with plenty of cheeky British humour and a parody of Tolkien tropes.

- Controlling your minions is as fun as ever. They are a lively bunch, scooping over their targets in a frenzy, picking up helmets and swords and what not for their own use. Their delight in evil is hilarious and strangely endearing.

- The four types of minions have different abilities, strengths and weaknesses. Acquiring each type is a quest in itself, and then you get to utilise them in various combat puzzles during the rest of the game.

- If it's your thing (it's not my thing) you can customise your evil base, invest in different buffs and level up your gear and your minions. There's a whole metagame in there.

- The story never takes itself too seriously, and the whole thing has a light, fun feel to it.

- It's an open world, and you can switch between quests at your leisure, there's no linearity.

- I'm glad there's now a minimap - Overlord 1 didn't have one and it was pain to navigate sometimes. Much better here.

The bad stuff:

- The minions might be fast and nimble, but your player character (the Overlord) is as slow and lumbering as he was in OL1. I get that it's supposed to be this way - you're the heavy tank and they're the quick little rogues - but your slowness is really tedious when much of your play time is spent slowly tromping from point to point. Yes there are portals, but not often enough.

- Controls can be rather fiddly. You're trying to manage 4 different minion groups, setting waypoints, moving them around, while also moving yourself and fighting with your own weapons and spells.

- I haven't finished the game. At least not as of this review. Maybe because I played OL1 and started this right away, but I got rather bored at some point. And the slow movement pace really doesn't help.

----------------

Overall, this gets a big recommendation from me. I suggest you start with playing Overlord 1: Raising Hell, then take a break, then start with Overlord 2.

reviewText:
Overlord's a pretty unique game. You play as an evil Overlord who commands a small army of goblin-like minions to do his dirty work for him. At the outset, you'll be able to keep 15 under your control at a time, and that number will rise as you move forward in the story. There's something viscerally satisfying watching your minions wreak havoc on an enemy town - the little guys gleefully destroying everything in sight while the occupants run around in terror, many of them with a minion or two clinging to their backs and clubbing them to death. Mayhem and chaos ensues and it's entertaining to watch, and you can wade into the fray and knock things around with a huge axe if you don't feel like sitting on the sidelines.

If it sounds too dark, don't worry - the game has a great morbid sense of humor and doesn't try to play it straight, so it's never depressing or disturbing. The game pokes fun at fantasy conventions too - early on you make enemies of the elves, who are literal tree-hugging hippies who are pretty upset that you've been clubbing baby seals to death to harvest life force for your growing army. The primary villians are a Roman-style Empire, who are rounding up and killing magic beings (like you and your minions), and the story takes jabs at ancient Rome sterotypes. Your senior minion advisor also narrates things for you, and the detest he expresses for the more beautiful side of fantasy settings is pretty hilarious.

The game plays well, but there are problems with the controls. Later on, combat demands precise control over your minions, and the game doesn't really do that well enough. It leads to some frustrating moments where you're fumbling around trying to give the right orders to your minions, while your enemies are picking them off - giving you a taste of the confusion you normally cause. Some of the genre's typical sins come here too - there's a couple of clunky vehicle sequences, and at least one forced stealth section. To the game's credit, these segments aren't nearly as infuriating as you'd expect, but they still felt unnecessary and weren't very fun.

Overall it's a fun game, and I recommend it despite its shortcomings - especially to players who enjoy summoner" type characters in other action RPGs (such as Diablo)

reviewText:
S great concept and a fun game.  Very limited so dont expect too much depth or much longevity even if, like me, you try and squeeze every last drop of entertainment out of  it because you like the concept so much.   It has a very quirky style and some progression which makes you feel like your doing a little more than reading a script.  But it is so very linear that even some clever game design cannot really hide it.

There is no open world and the way the progression is limited within the context of the game can be obvious enough to be annoying.

However, its on sale a lot and while I wouldnt pay full price.  For the low price I paid it was worth it.

I like the game for its humour and quirkiness but it could have been so very much more.  What I would have liked to see would have been the following:

Open world
Better development of the tower less tied into obvious story markers.
Remove every trace of being a linear progression.
Less puzzle solving, more battle.
More depth in the management of captured towns and cities with the effort making it harder or easier to defend.
All round depth.

Getting a thumbs up because it is well worth buying..

reviewText:
While I could never personally get into the Pikmin series, Overlord 1 and 2 had me enthralled after a half an hour of play. While the main mechanics of the game are very similar to Pikmin, with minions that have different abilities such as being able to cross water, fire, etc. the game also features spell system that the player can take advantage of as well as the ability to use multiple types of melee weapons.

Another big difference between Pikmin and the Overlord series is the tone and story of the game. Pikmin is a more child friendly game, while Overlord is definitely more geared towards the adult audience with a story that is actually fairly well written and not so generic with the premise, as you are actually kind of the villian in these games.

The graphics have a different style than most games, with a very claylike feel that you will notice more in the winter areas of the game. Not to say that the visuals are bad by any means, they're just not outstanding.

Definitely worth picking up if you can get a good price on these games. Just a warning, the first game is a little more dated in visuals as it's a bit older but it's still not eye-bleedingly terrible.

I tried to like Overlord II, but it wasn’t easy.  This isn’t an awful game, but it's not one that I would recommend to others.

To me the controls seem a bit odd, certain actions like sweeping with the minions are strange.  Other controls like madly clicking the left mouse button over and over will leave you with a permanently damaged digit.  The premise of the game is a let down too.  The summary states that you finally get to play as the bad guy, I was hoping for something far less cartoony and silly.

Most of the game is trying to figure out how to get certain types of minions to complete a certain puzzle so that you can progress in the weak story.

I’ll have to check out the original Overlord and see if it’s any better.

Pros
This is a very unique game.  I don’t think you will find anything like it.Cons
Graphics are a little ugly, the game doesn’t look great.
The game just feels like a variety of pointless puzzles that you have to overcome in order to cause some comical mischief with your minions.

reviewText:
Big improvement over the original. Still not as good as it should be.

If you played the first game and actually liked it, you'll love this game. Everything is better fleshed out here. Upgrades to the tower serve more of a purpose. Art is better. You can actually sit on the throne in this game. You don't get handmaidens this time but you get more mistresses. You get a minimap in this game, finally.

You feel like more of an overlord in this game. Rather than being split into evil and eviler (which was really good and evil when you added it all up) This game splits between domination and destruction. Either you're here to conquer or to watch the world burn. You can dominate villagers and actually put them to work for you producing goods. There will be tribute waiting for you with each visit. The game is also focused more on actual inflitration and battle and less on arbitrary puzzles.

But its not perfect. The humor is as bad as it was in the first game. Very cheesy, very obvious and not in an over the top good way. You also aren't going to feel like this is your character but that was a problem in the first game. And the adviser is still calling the shots. You have to do basically what he says.

If you can catch this on sale and you're looking for some hack and slash with minor tactical elements, this game is fun enough to justify itself.

Dissapointing. After all that work to conquer and acquire in Overlord 1, we find that this edition is the same story. The last overlord defeated (how?), you must rise up and rebuild his empire. Oh look, the hives are lost again, and the entire game will consist of finding them in a series of convoluted puzzles. New enemy moves everywhere, yay! I like that part. I REALLY like the formation and panic mechanics. There were definitely better mechanics to deal with combat wise, if only they weren't built around puzzles.

I have to say though that most of the new moves and features contribute to the endless one-off mini-games. Puzzles puzzles everywhere. what happened to just marching through blowing everything up and overwhelming it with my minions? Pity that nearly every battle is now a minion-movement puzzle. And I mean EVERY battle. No more overwhelming your enemies quickly or charging in yourself.

Forging is now pre-set recipes, and my preferred recipes are nowhere to be found. I guess winning isn't on the menu. Playing with the best recipes I could find I still felt profoundly inferior to my character from overlord 1.

Add in the nany engine prevening me from auto targeting the intentionally irritating townsfolk, the cliched way the bad guys ALWAYS get the drop on me (I detest cutscene combat), and the fact that I cannot even farm up life-force for the war of attrition anymore (yes, farming spots exist, WAY out where they are hard to get to, they normally only occur as the plot progresses).

My final opinion? Some wanna be genius in marketing or senior management decided to re-target this at a younger,  stupider audience, while forgetting that it is a game concept that attracts older, more intelligent customers. It could have been done SO much better.

Furthermore, you yourself can enter the battle wieilding a giant sword in one hand and magic in the other, and so you can choose exactly how to approach enemies. From afar with fire-throwing minions? Up close in a head on attack? Spider-mounted spiders for a sneak attack?

• Great funny story and really good voice acting. Furthermore, the emphasis on the need to do evil is, quite frankly, hilarious.


Cons:

This game was worth every penny of its' $ 60.00 purchase price value when it was released, and it is a complete steal for the $ 9.99 price now!  Now don't be fooled by the amount of hours I have played this game on my account on steam, I have played this game on both steam, xbox 360 and pc physical box cd, and each time I bought it, it was worth it!  There are a few bugs and issues and complaints I have for this game, but nothing that overall takes away from the game's experience.  Now I guess I should mention that my love for this game may be a bit biased towards this game, because during my 16th year this game saved me from a manic depression state, but I've looked at this game in a cynical viewpoint and I can still say that it is worth buying and worth all the support you can give it.

Pros & Cons:  Now comes the part where I talk about the issues I had with the game from my cynical viewpoint.  To be fair, this game does have a very linear path before you, but you can make choices that change the outcome of the game; unlike the first game, you cannot choose to be good or evil, you can only be evil this time round.  There are a few bugs that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off through-out my seventh playthrough; for example, in my seventh playthrough, I have gotten 100% EVERYTHING, I got all upgrades and I made all the destruction choices... but despite my choices... I still got the neutral ending.  I'm not the only person who has suffered this bug, appearantly every other fan of this game has suffered this bug as well, not one person was able to access the destruction ending, or the Dominance ending, that needs to be fixed for their next game!!  Now the game has some very funny banter and witty social commentary with what's wrong in the world today (spoilers!)  At one point you have to cause global warming by melting the polar ice caps for example.  The combat system and animations in this game, are better than in the last game and look a lot more badass.  There is a hidden love plot between the Overlord and the Irish Mistress kelda, but unfortunately the developers did nothing with it; disapointing, because I wanted to see those two get married at the end if you choose her as your main mistress.

Alright, so that's it with the game.  Please understand that this game is still worth the money, and is one of my all time Favorites; if you love fantasy, if you love both crude and witty humor with a little bit of social commentary with a small love story told in the middle of a dark age, you will love this game.  I promise you, you will love this game.

Overlord 2 is a very decent puzzle game.  Yes it is essentially a puzzle game.  You have to figure out how to get from A to B and do C with minimal casualties.
You play as the dark Overlord battling a powerful ruler who's bent on ridding the world of magic.

1. Think carefully how to achieve your objectives.  Throwing in your minions without thought is a good way to get them killed.

The bad:
3. Some rather tedious bits.
4. More autosave spots are needed in certain areas.
5. The minions like to run off far away from where I directed them.
6. I would have like a better stats system.  What is the difference between two minions in terms of attack and defense?  What about the armor and weapons you craft?

The ugly:
7. My game crashed every time I switched to desktop.  Also other crashes.  Not so bad that I could not play.

The game is worth playing.  It just did not blow me away.  Too often it made me curse in frustration.

I loved the original Overlord, it was cool, fun, creative, and kinda funny. When I played Overlord 2, I still enjoyed it, but I did feel a little disappointed. Overlord 2 still has the creativeness, fun, and comedy of the original Overlord, but it just doesn't feel the same.
There are some things I like about this game. I like the new micromanagement with the minions, and I enjoyed destroying or enslaving towns. Another thing I liked was the improved graphics. Also, there is FINALLY a minimap. The soundtrack is also really good. Also, since you can have 3 mistresses in this game, you have more options on decorating your Tower.The story is really good and very well-written. The tone and humor of the original is still there, and it is very good. Also, the voice actor for Gnarl has reprised his role in this game and i appreciate Codemasters going that extra mile.
Now for the stuff I don't like about this game. The campaign is really linear and an hour shorter than the original's campaign which ends with 3 dissappointing endings. They also foolishly removed steel, durium, and arcanium. I also encountered a couple game crashes. For example, when I was gnome hunting, when i hit a tree a couple times to get the gnomes on it down so I could kill them, the game crashed. I did this again and it crashed again. So, when you are gnome hunting, don't hit the trees too much, cuz apparrently the game will punish you for it. Also, the magic is really more restricted than it was in the first game because there's only 3 magic types; minions, halo, and domination. Also, the morality system is really disappointing in this game. You see, you have a choice between Domination or Destruction. Domination is where you can mind control the people of the place you conquered to serve you. Destruction is where you can just destroy the place by killing all the people. I see domination and destruction as equal levels of evil. Also, the final boss is really disappointing. To beat the final boss, you have to destroy his weak points located across his body. So, you have to use your green or red minions to destroy them. Disappointing, I know. After a while it gets really boring. Like I said before, you are greeted with three disappointing endings after the final boss.
Overlord 2 is a good game, but it is not one of my favorites like the original was. I recommend this to die hard Overlord fans and if you're not one, then you should try the original before playing this one.

I like measuring games by pros and cons. So let me tell you about Overlord II.

Pros:
+The game has a lovable sense of humor. Sure it may not make you laugh your ♥♥♥ off a lot of the time but it also doesn't make you want to turn the game off. If your sense of humor saves you from that then that's how you know your sense of humor is good.
+The need to gain power is real! I can't really describe it but whenever I play the game I really feel like... progressing.
+The game has an interesting soundtrack. Maybe not memorable but interesting to say the least. That's a pro in itself.
+Your Overlord can rock that gothic look like no other! The armor and weapons you can craft look AWESOME!

Cons:
-The combat's a bit stubby. Sometimes you may struggle to smash something with your mace or axe or whatever. You also may find the target-lock system for magic use is also a bit stubby. It doesn't make the game unplayable but it's also hard to ignore.
-Minion control can and WILL be annoying sometimes. Again it doesn't make certain areas impossible but it's still hard to ignore.
-Animations are kinda lame. I mean, Cinematic animations are alright but in-game ones are kinda poorly done. Lip syncing and all.
-The ending is not only lame but also kind of abrupt. You kill the final boss. Own everything. F*ck b*tches. Get money. The end.
-There's no big replay value. There's three endings as far as I'm aware but all of which are lame and only show ONE different cutscene each. Spoiler alert. You always win no matter what. The closest thing to a 'bad' ending this game has is the normal one.

My opinion. It's an alright game. Has plenty of nicks but most of them aren't entirely noticable. I'd give it a 6/10 at least.

In my review of Overlord I, I took issue with the conflicted themes presented by the game. It constant insisted that I was an evil Overlord spreading evil across the land. But it was in stark contrast to the game mechanics and story that I largely felt made the Overlord more of an anti-hero than anything else. Overlord I failed at its objective of treating you like a Lord of Evil in my mind. However, Overlord II didn’t.

Overall Story Thoughts
You are the new Overlord. The story starts with you being scouted and tested as a Overlad by Gnarl. Eventually, it leads to you being banished from the mountain village where you grew up, doing lots of damage to the town’s betrayal and going into The Netherworld. After you grow up, your job is to strike out from The Netherworld to the lands above. To set the lands in darkness and/or to conquer the minds of men. To find the one ring, to rule them all and in the darkness bind them.

Originally posted by KingIsaacLinksr:Uhh...hold on one second, this explanation of the story sounds off. Let me grab the notes I have…rustles through paper...AHA! Here it is. Whoops. It uhh, hehe, isn’t this. My bad, back to the review of Overlord II.
Ok, so there is no one ring and the overall plot is a bit odd. You go from town to town, dominating or destroying everything. Putting down a few rebellions and finding out what happened to The Tower Heart of the past game. All the while the Glorious Empire is constantly trying to stop you and/or take over the world. It then concludes in a rather long and drawn out siege of a castle. Culminating in a fight against a great, monstrous evil. Yeah, unfortunately the game doesn’t quite stick the landing with the ending. I would have rather fought a more “good-guy” bad guy such as some Holy Knight or a Julius Caesar character (to fit the Roman-esque theme they were going for). Someone who was actually trying to defend their people or ideals rather than their own selfish desires. Ok, maybe Julius was a bad example but I think you get the point I’m trying to make. Ultimately, I feel like they missed out on what could have been a really solid ending.

Overlord II's Themes
That all said, it’s these little touches and more that I probably forgot to mention that give you the sense of becoming a lord of darkness. While the corny humour is still present, it feels restrained enough to compliment the dark themes at play. In this case, less is more as the times that it tries to be funny actually work, rather than backfire and become tiresome. Overall, it’s a great thematic improvement to the original title.

The Combat System
As a whole, the combat fluctuates from reasonably challenging to borderline-ridiculously-spammy. Some enemies are a little too quirky for my taste and can flatten armies in seconds. Which I can’t really decide if I like or not. But what I do like is the pacing of the combat. Not only does it have a diverse range of enemies and fights but it also has stealth sections. Multiple sections of the game require you to take control of a single minion and lead the army without the Overlord’s body and complete the objective with what minions you have. This stealth aspect really adds a nice change of pace to prevent the RTS-esque fights from getting too samey or overdone. It’s also pretty forgiving as there aren’t any instant failure states. I really enjoyed these sections and they were a welcome addition.

PC Settings & Multiplayer
Visually, this game is much better than the previous. Lush forests, sunny beaches and cold mountain villages really spice the world up. Most of the settings for Overlord II (Video, Audio & Controls) are changeable in the game’s launcher. There’s options for pretty much every custom visual setting I can think of. Most are on/off switches with Texture Detail, Debris Detail, Shadow Detail, View Distance and Particle Detail having sliders. Separate audio sliders are included (in-game) for sound, music and speech with support for up to 8.1 surround sound. Controller and keyboard + mouse are supported with key remappings for both. Controller is, in my opinion, the most optimal. Overall, the game is well optimized with consistent framerates and good looking visuals. Outside of the one crash I experienced, (towards the end of the game), the game seems relatively stable. I didn’t get a chance to experience the multiplayer because either the servers are down or no one is playing the game.

Final Thoughts
Overlord II enhances everything about the first game. It brings a more consistent theme, new minion abilities & spells, lusher environments and a feeling of being a true Overlord. It doesn’t quite stick the landing though. The story’s last chapter is drawn out and the ultimate bad guy you get to fight is disappointing. The combat is better this time with subterfuge, new enemies and different tactics/spells that can be used. But it’s still….janky at times when I don’t think it should be. There’s a good amount of content though, you'll definitely get your fill of each place the game can take you to. The replay value is a bit weak especially with multiplayer not functioning. Ultimately, this Overlord game was actually a fun time despite my problems with the combat system. The combat is improved enough that I can recommend it. With the caveat to expect frustration while dealing with some of the more eccentric bosses and monsters. Still, evil did find a way, to be fun and enjoyable. So, kudos to Triumph for that.

I loved the original Overlord, it was cool, fun, creative, and kinda funny. When I played Overlord 2, I still enjoyed it, but I did feel a little disappointed. Overlord 2 still has the creativeness, fun, and comedy of the original Overlord, but it just doesn't feel the same.
There are some things I like about this game. I like the new micromanagement with the minions, and I enjoyed destroying or enslaving towns. Another thing I liked was the improved graphics. Also, there is FINALLY a minimap. The soundtrack is also really good. Also, since you can have 3 mistresses in this game, you have more options on decorating your Tower.The story is really good and very well-written. The tone and humor of the original is still there, and it is very good. Also, the voice actor for Gnarl has reprised his role in this game and i appreciate Codemasters going that extra mile.
Now for the stuff I don't like about this game. The campaign is really linear and an hour shorter than the original's campaign which ends with 3 dissappointing endings. They also foolishly removed steel, durium, and arcanium. I also encountered a couple game crashes. For example, when I was gnome hunting, when i hit a tree a couple times to get the gnomes on it down so I could kill them, the game crashed. I did this again and it crashed again. So, when you are gnome hunting, don't hit the trees too much, cuz apparrently the game will punish you for it. Also, the magic is really more restricted than it was in the first game because there's only 3 magic types; minions, halo, and domination. Also, the morality system is really disappointing in this game. You see, you have a choice between Domination or Destruction. Domination is where you can mind control the people of the place you conquered to serve you. Destruction is where you can just destroy the place by killing all the people. I see domination and destruction as equal levels of evil. Also, the final boss is really disappointing. To beat the final boss, you have to destroy his weak points located across his body. So, you have to use your green or red minions to destroy them. Disappointing, I know. After a while it gets really boring. Like I said before, you are greeted with three disappointing endings after the final boss.
Overlord 2 is a good game, but it is not one of my favorites like the original was. I recommend this to die hard Overlord fans and if you're not one, then you should try the original before playing this one.

I like measuring games by pros and cons. So let me tell you about Overlord II.

Pros:
+The game has a lovable sense of humor. Sure it may not make you laugh your ♥♥♥ off a lot of the time but it also doesn't make you want to turn the game off. If your sense of humor saves you from that then that's how you know your sense of humor is good.
+The need to gain power is real! I can't really describe it but whenever I play the game I really feel like... progressing.
+The game has an interesting soundtrack. Maybe not memorable but interesting to say the least. That's a pro in itself.
+Your Overlord can rock that gothic look like no other! The armor and weapons you can craft look AWESOME!

Cons:
-The combat's a bit stubby. Sometimes you may struggle to smash something with your mace or axe or whatever. You also may find the target-lock system for magic use is also a bit stubby. It doesn't make the game unplayable but it's also hard to ignore.
-Minion control can and WILL be annoying sometimes. Again it doesn't make certain areas impossible but it's still hard to ignore.
-Animations are kinda lame. I mean, Cinematic animations are alright but in-game ones are kinda poorly done. Lip syncing and all.
-The ending is not only lame but also kind of abrupt. You kill the final boss. Own everything. F*ck b*tches. Get money. The end.
-There's no big replay value. There's three endings as far as I'm aware but all of which are lame and only show ONE different cutscene each. Spoiler alert. You always win no matter what. The closest thing to a 'bad' ending this game has is the normal one.

My opinion. It's an alright game. Has plenty of nicks but most of them aren't entirely noticable. I'd give it a 6/10 at least.
